The "Las Poderosas" (The Powerful Ones) communal bank will start the first cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Santiago II regional office. It is made up of eight members and it is directed by a board, of which María is the President. The communal bank members have a variety of businesses. Among them are selling sportswear, selling ice cream, selling food, dressmaking shop, buying and selling cattle, and selling food.

The loan they will take out will help small microbusinesswomen. María is one of them. She says that she joined Pro Mujer a year ago at the invitation of a friend who is a customer of the institution. Currently she has a dressmaking shop; she makes it known that she started this business several years ago upon working as a saleswoman in a clothing store. Subsequently she started an independent business with her savings, since she already knew the market.

The loan she is now taking out is to increase capital (buying wholesale fabric) that she will acquire from the wholesale sellers in the city of La Paz and after production she will sell it at her stand. This form of work allows her to generate resources to support her family financially, since she is single and has three children.

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responds that she likes the savings the institution offers.

loans.use: to buy wholesale fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy poultry

loans.name: Beatriz  Del Carmen

texts.es: Beatriz de 30 años de edad se dedica desde hace varios años a la crianza de cerdos, comercializa los cerdos en los diferentes mercados, con las ventas que realiza logra salir adelante con los gastos del hogar, ella vive en casa propia con su compañero de vida y su hijo, Beatriz está solicitando un crédito para poder comprar de 3 cerdos y concentrado y así poder continuar con la crianza de los mismo y tener mejores ganancias.
texts.en: Beatriz, 30 years old, has earned a living raising pigs for several years. She sells the pigs in various marketplaces. With the sales she makes she manages to cover her household costs. She lives in her own home with her life partner and son. Beatriz is requesting a loan in order to buy 3 pigs and food concentrate and in that way be able to continue raising the same and have better earnings.

loans.use: to buy 3 pigs and food concentrate.

loans.name: Marina De Jesus

texts.es: Marina se dedica desde hace 25 años a la elaboración de antojitos como: tostadas de tajaditas de papas, yuca, platanitos, etc. su negocio lo tiene ubicado en un lugar muy transitado cerca de su lugar de residencia, por esa razón posee mucha clientela, Marina vive en casa propia con sus dos hijas, su nieto y su esposo, ella esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de materia prima como: yuca, papa, plátanos, aceite, etc. todo por mayor para la elaboración de estos alimentos y así obtener mejores ganancias para darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Marina has had a business making snacks for 25 years.  She makes food such as chips made from potatoes, cassava, plantains, etc.  Her business is located in a place with many passers-by that is near her home.  This is why she has a lot of customers.  Marina lives in her own home with her 2 daughters, her grandchild, and her husband.  She is requesting a loan to buy supplies such as: cassava, potatoes, plantains, etc., at wholesale to make her snacks.  This way, she can obtain more earnings and give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy cassava, potatoes, plantains, and other supplies at wholesale

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en: Anthony, 52, earns a living by supplying tents, chairs, and musical instruments for functions, and he also sells second-hand clothes and rents houses. He and his wife have two children and live in Fort Portal, Uganda. With the profits from his business, he has been able to build rental houses. He tells us that his primary business challenge is irresponsible customers who break his chairs and mishandle the tents leading to losses. His business plan is to eventually own an events company. Anthony intends to use the loan to buy men's suits to sell.

loans.use: to buy men's suits to sell.

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en: Iliya is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Iliya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Simon, Felisa and Anock.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Iliya would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Iliya can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Iliya  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Clementina's Group

texts.en:
Clementina is 56 years old and has nine children. She has been a farmer for more than 30 years and is always said to be a very experienced farmer. Even though Clementina is the only one featured in the above picture, she is actually representing her group, formed by 10 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya.

Clementina started working alongside One Acre Fund a few years ago, in 2011. She decided to do so, because she wanted to earn enough to feed her family. Since then, she has seen her life improve, especially in the sense that she has been able to feed her family consistently. This year she decided to represent her group, because she wanted to help more farmers.

Clementina’s Group will receive farming inputs to plant a total of 6.5 acres of land. In addition, some of the One Acre Fund farmers will be purchasing a solar light this season, so with this loan, Clementina's Group will receive one solar light.

loans.use: to buy cost-efficient maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming planting season.

loans.name: Harrison's Group

texts.en: Harrison is a 47-year-old Komaza tree farmer (his hand is raised in the picture). He has five children, all of whom are in school. Harrison is married and his spouse is a farmer too. In addition to growing trees, Harrison also cultivates subsistence crops; he supports his family with farming. He decided to join Komaza to improve his living standard and plans to spend the money earned from the Komaza tree farm to pay his children's school fees. Harrison’s favorite part about working with Komaza is the training.

loans.use: to purchase tree farm planting inputs, such as seedlings, and pay for technical training and planting support.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is a maize farmer from Auchan village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Mohammed would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater to his immediate cash needs. With this loan, and Babban Gona’s support, Mohammed can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Mohammed, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Rosas De Pucuro Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ROSAS DE PUCURO” iniciará el quinto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Achacachi, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Luisa es la Tesorera. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de queso, venta de papa, venta de pescado.
 
El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Luisa es integrante, ella indica que es la primer año que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de un Asesor de la institución que fue a visitarle a su domicilio. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de pesca; nos cuenta que este negocio lo aprendió de sus padres, pues desde niña apoyaba en el negocio familiar, ahora que tiene una familia independiente decide emprender su propio negocio.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de red) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de la Ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo implementará en su espacio de trabajo. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, ya que ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones y la atención de la institución ofrece.

En la imagen no esta presente una de las socias, ya que tuvo que ir a realizar actividades laborales y se fue con premura.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Rosas de Pucuro” will start its fifth loan cycle in Pro Mujer, as part of the Centro Focal de Achacachi. It is formed by eight members and it is managed by a board of directors in which Luisa is the Treasurer. The businesses that the members of the communal bank have are diverse, and among them are the sale of cheese, potatoes and fish. 

The loan they are requesting will benefit the micro-entrepreneurs in which Luisa is a member. She says that it’s her first year at Pro Mujer, and she entered by the request of an advisor of the institution who visited her at her house. Nowadays, she has a fishing business, and says that she learned this activity from her parents, since from a young age she had to help in the family business. Now that she has her own family she decided to start her own business. 

The loan she is now requesting is to increase her capital (buy nets) that will be acquired from the wholesalers of the city La Paz. Then she will use them at her place of work. This type of work allows her to generate incomes to support her family, since she is married and has three children.  

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answers that she likes the training and attention that the institution offers them. 

One of the members does not appear in the picture, since she had to go to work and left early.

loans.use: to buy nets.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 8 years, Rose has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more types of clothes for sale, and will help Rose to generate greater profits and improve more on her clothing business. Rose hopes that in the future she will be able to have a well stocked boutique. 

Rose is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rose who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more types of clothes to sell

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina is a 47-year-old married woman from Qabatiya, a village near Jenin City. She lives with her husband and four kids (two sons and two daughters) in a simple house.

Lina's husband is an employee in a local firm with a low income. This income barely covers all their needs. Lina works on the family land where she plants seasonal crops and olive trees. She sells the olive oil in the local market. Lina would like to improve her business and expand it.

Lina took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help her to buy more olive seedlings for her farm. This will increase the farm productivity and also the income. Lina appears in the photo on her land.

loans.use: to buy more olive seedlings for her farm

loans.name: Glades

texts.en:
GLADES is 33 years old, and lives in the town of Fortportal in the Fortpotal region of Uganda. She is a widow, and has 2 children who are currently in school. For the past 8 years, Glades has been working hard to manage her food store, which sells food like maize flour. 

To help expand her business, Glades has requested a loan of 3,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food products for sale, and will help Glades to generate greater profits and take care of her family's basic needs. Glades hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Glades is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Glades who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more food products for sale

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 30 years old and lives in the town of Fortportal, in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is currently in school. For the past 10 years, Alice has been working hard to manage her beauty salon, where she does hair dressing.

To help expand her business, Alice has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more hair dryers and relaxers, to attract more clients. It will help Alice to generate greater profits and take care of her sick mother. Alice hopes that in the future she will be able to have a healthy family.

Alice is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Alice, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more hair dryers and relaxers to attract more clients

loans.name: Beatriz Mercedes

texts.es: Beatriz es una señora muy amable, ella tiene 66 años de edad y se dedica 3 años  a  la venta de ropa por catálogo y ofreciendo a sus clientas, amigas  y vecinas, su esposo trabaja de chofer, y tienen 3 hijas, Beatriz necesita el crédito para comprar ropa y asi mejorar y variar mas las prendas que ofrece, y  ahí lograr tener más clientela y mejorar sus ingresos para apoyar a su esposo en los gastos del hogar.
texts.en: Beatriz is a very kind woman. She is 66 years old. For 3 years she has sold clothing through a catalog and has offered it to her customers, friends and neighbors. Her husband works as a driver and they have 3 daughters. Beatriz needs the loan to buy clothing and thus improve and have more variety in the clothing she offers, and thus succeed in having more customers and improving her income in order to support her husband with the household expenses.

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: Benard's Group

texts.en:
Benard, pictured above, is a group leader and is representing his group, formed by 12 farmers in Teso District, Kenya. He joined One Acre Fund for the first time in 2011 and decided to represent his group because he wanted to be more active in his community. He is married and has 3 children.

With a portion of this loan, Benard will not only purchase maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, but also a solar light. Receiving a solar light as part of his loan means that now he will be able to reduce his consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money. Benard plans to use the profits he gains this year to send his children to school.

In total, Benard’s Group will use the inputs received from this loan to plant a total of 5.25 acres of land. They will also receive a total of 10 solar lights.

loans.use: to buy cost-efficient maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, as well as a solar light.

loans.name: Sahabi

texts.en: Sahabi is a maize farmer from Kwankwani Village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Sahabi would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Sahabi can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Sahabi, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Erik Oswaldo

texts.es: Erik es un joven de 23 años de edad, el vive con sus padres y con sus hermanos, comenta que sus padres son comerciantes de papas y que es de ahí que él siguió su ejemplo, Erik se dedica al comercio de papas y dice que su negocio es familiar, también se dedica a trabajar de fotógrafo cuando lo contratan, Erik  se dedica a compra papas en el campo en donde están haciendo las cosechas y luego las comercializa en los mercados de papas, el crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de mercadería en papa para seguir adelante en su negocio, la aspiración de Erik es mejorar su negocio y con las ganancia que le quede desea reunir un capital para comprarse una cámara fotográfica y seguir con sus dos negocios.
texts.en: Erik is a 23 year old youth. He lives with his parents and brothers. He says that his parents are potato sellers and that it is from there that he has continued the example. Erik earns a living selling potatoes and says that it is a family business. He also works as a photographer when contracted. Erik buys the potatoes from the farms where they are harvested and then sells them in the potato markets. He is going to invest the loan in buying potatoes wholesale to continue forward with his business. Erik’s inspiration is to improve his business and with the extra earnings he wishes to raise money to buy himself a photographer’s camera and continue with his two businesses.

loans.use: to buy potatoes wholesale.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: el joven a quien se le ha pixeleado a cara por tener 26 años de edad y vivir en zona de alto riesgo se dedica a la venta de pan dulce vende de manera ambulante por las diferentes colonias y tiene muchos clientes, el joven vive en casa propia con su madre, el esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas pan dulce por mayor para poder continuar con sus ventas y asi poder tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en: The young man, whose face has been pixelated because he is 26 years old and lives in a high-risk area, sells sweet bread as a street vendor in the different neighborhoods and has many customers. He lives in his own house with his mother. He is asking for a loan to buy more wholesale sweet bread in order to be able to continue with his sales and in this way be able to have a better income.

loans.use: to buy more wholesale sweet bread

loans.name: Las Sirenitas Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “LAS SIRENITAS” iniciará el quinto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Santiago II, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Lidia es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de comida, venta de cosméticos, venta de polleras y enaguas, venta de masitas, venta de ropa, tienda de barrio, venta de CD’s, servicio de transporte.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Lidia es integrante, ella indica que hace cuatro años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una amiga que es cliente de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio venta de ropa; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió hace varios años al observar el mercado y ver que este producto es ampliamente comercializado. 

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de ropa por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo comercializará en su puesto de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The "Las Sirenitas" communal bank will start its fifth cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Santiago II regional office. It is made up of eight members and is directed by a board, of which Lidia is the President. The communal bank members have a variety of businesses. Among them are selling food, selling cosmetics, selling polleras and enaguas [traditional skirts], selling small cakes, selling clothing, neighborhood store, selling CDs, and a transportation service.

The loan they will take out will benefit small microbusinesswomen. Lidia is one of them. She says that she joined Pro Mujer four years ago at the invitation of a friend who is a customer of the institution. Currently, she has a business selling clothing; she makes it known that she started this business several years ago upon observing the market and seeing that this product is widely sold.

The loan that she will now take out is to increase capital (buying wholesale clothing) that she will acquire from the wholesale sellers in the city of La Paz and will subsequently sell at her stand. This form of work allows her to generate resources to support her family financially, since she is married and has three children.

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responds that she likes the trainings the institution offers.

loans.use: to buy wholesale clothing

loans.name: Mary Gorret

texts.en:
Gorret is 35 years old and lives in the town of Fortportal in the Fortpotal region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, who are all currently in school. 

For the past five years, Gorret has been working hard to manage her business selling timber. 

To help expand her business, Gorret has requested a loan of UGX 2,500,000 from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more timber for sale.  It will help Gorret to generate greater profits and pay some of her children's school fees. 

Gorret hopes that in the future she will be able to earn more income for her family. 

Gorret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Gorret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more timber to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 40 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is a widow and has four children with two of them currently in school. For the past five years, Joyce has been working hard to manage her Drug shop, which sells drugs. 

To help expand her business, Joyce has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drugs and other items for the drug shop, and will help Joyce to generate greater profits and help in improving her family's standard of living. Joyce hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the drug shop into a patients clinic. 

Joyce is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joyce who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more drugs and other items for the drug shop

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 32 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fortpotal region of Uganda. He is married and has 3 children with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, John has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells essential items like sugar and soap .

To help expand his business, John has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential items like sugar, soap, water, and bread for sale, and will help John to generate greater profits and take care of his family by providing for enough basic needs. John hopes that in the future he will be able to buy a plot of land and build more rental houses.

John is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like John who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more essential items to sell

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin is 55 years old and lives in the town of Budibugyo in the Fortpotal region of Uganda. He is married and has six children, with one of them currently in school. 

For the past three years, Benjamin has been working hard to manage his boutique, which sells clothes. 

To help expand his business, Benjamin has requested a loan of UGX 2,500,000 from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for sale.  It will help Benjamin to generate greater profits and improving his family's standard of living. 

Benjamin hopes that in the future he will be able to expand the business into wholesale. 

Benjamin is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Benjamin who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for his boutique

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase some appliances for her house.

loans.name: Abdulhamid

texts.en: Abdulhamid is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Abdulhamid would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Abdulhamid can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Abdulhamid is looking  to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: William's Group

texts.en:
William's Group is formed by 13 farmers in Teso District and is being represented by William, who is the group leader pictured above. He is 45 years old, married, and has 3 children. William has been a farmer for 15 years and is often referred to as a very reliable person.

William isn’t new to One Acre Fund; he actually joined the program in 2012 and has since noticed his life has changed; especially in the sense that he has a larger farm group support ever since. This year, William will not only get fertilizer and maize seeds as part of his loan, but will also purchase a solar light. He is very excited about this addition since now he will have light during dark hours for his children to be able to study.

Using this loan, William's Group will purchase a total of 10 solar lights and use the farming inputs received to plant a total of 7.25 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light, as well as hybrid seeds and fertilizer to improve harvest of maize.

loans.name: Valerik

texts.en:
Valerik is a 59-year-old married woman. She lives with her husband, her son, daughter-in-law and two grandchildren in Khashtarak village. The family is actively involved in agricultural activities. Specifically, they have livestock including cows, calves, a pig, hens and bee colonies and a plot of agricultural land, where they grow wheat, potatoes, and fruit trees,  selling the harvested products locally. 

Valerik has decided to purchase four calves and enlarge her farming business.  This will increase the family income and, with the increased income, Valerik will provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to pay for four calves

loans.name: Midress

texts.en:
Midress is a hard-working woman living in Kamwenge, Uganda. 

She owns a retail shop as her main source of income, but she also owns rentals for supplementary income.

It is from these businesses that she has been able to sustain herself and take care of her children.  Though she faces the challenge of a high rate of defaulters, she hopes to expand her business by building more rentals to increase her income and satisfy her dream.

Midress intends to use the loan to buy building materials (like stones) to finish building her rentals.

loans.use: to buy building materials (like stones) to finish building her rental property

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more soups, eggs, basic grains, soft drinks, candies, sweet bread, etc.

loans.name: Tadeo

texts.en:
Tadeo, who is 49 years old, lives in Bundibugyo in Uganda. He is married and has ten children. 

He deals in buying and selling of cocoa, but he also has a cocoa garden. He started this business in 2004.  He has managed it well and is proud of it. 

He wants a loan to buy cocoa for resale.  He hopes to pay school fees for his children and build a permanent house.

loans.use: To buy cocoa for resale

loans.name: Alifunsi

texts.en: Alifunsi is a fifty-seven-year-old hard-working married man. He is charged with the responsibility of taking care of 15 children ranging in age from 8 to 18, seven of whom attend school. Alifunsi deals in produce, mainly buying and selling of maize and beans, among other items, in Hoima Uganda. He desires to expand and develop his business, as well as  educating his children. He will use the loan to buy more maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy more maize to sell.

loans.name: Silvard

texts.en:
Silvard is a 59-year-old woman who lives with her son, daughter-in-law and two grandchildren in the Syuniq region. Silvard is involved in agriculture. She keeps 20 hens and cultivates wheat, emmer wheat and potato. She sells the gathered harvest and gets income which is very important for her family's living. 

Silvard asks for this loan of USD 2,500 to purchase seeds (840 kgs), fertilizer and fuel for land cultivation. This loan will be a big support for Silvard's farming business and she hopes to enlarge her farming income.

loans.use: to pay for seeds (840 kgs), fertilizer and fuel for land cultivation

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose is 50 years old and has five children. She is a group leader and is representing her group formed by 11 farmers in Teso District, Kenya. 

Rose has been farming with One Acre Fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2010. This decision was largely a result of her desire to get the best quality fertilizer and hybrid seeds and, although she described her last harvest as good, she believes she could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside One Acre Fund. Rose also decided to purchase a solar light as part of her loan, which she is very excited about, as it will allow her to have light during dark hours for her children to be able to study.

Obtaining this loan means that Rose's Group will be able to receive a total of six solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 6.5 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Eziron

texts.en:
Eziron, who is 39 years old, is married with four children.  He lives in Bundibugyo in Uganda. 

He is a hard-working man who loves his business of selling fish. He started this business with an aim of seeing that his family get the basic needs of life. He also has a cocoa garden that helps to supplement his income from fishing.

Eziron wants a loan to buy cocoa and fish to resell.   He hopes to educate his children and expand his business into new market areas.

loans.use: to buy cocoa and fish to resell

loans.name: Bekim

texts.en:
Bekim wants to thank all of the lenders for their previous support. With that loan, he was able to purchase 10 sheep and renovate his stable roof. The loan   assisted him in reducing expenses on milk and milk products for his family, and helped keep his investment safe and protected from the upcoming harsh winter conditions. 

Now Bekim has started a business where he irons items for a restaurant in the area. He hopes that this is just the beginning of a new and successful enterprise as he seeks additional secure contracts with other restaurants and cafes in the area. Now, he is requesting another loan to purchase a new machine with which to iron. 

Bekim is very optimistic about this new business venture and looks forward to expanding in the future.

loans.use: To  purchase a new machine to iron

loans.name: Everlyne's Group

texts.en: Everlyne, pictured above, is often described as an extremely hard-working individual. She is 33 years old and as a group leader she is representing nine farmers in the Kakamega North District of Kenya. She is married and has four children. Everlyne is returning this season to work with One Acre Fund as this means that she is able to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods, which is why she decided to join in the first place. Everlyne says that she is happy to have made that decision because, since she first joined in 2012, she has been able to consistently feed her family, which has improved her day-to-day life significantly. Everlyne will use the profits from this season to save more money for the future. The group will use this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer to plant a total of five acres. Since some members of the group will also be purchasing a solar light with this loan, the group will also receive a total of five solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize	.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 49 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, with two of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Rosemary has been working hard to manage her small business, where she sells timber. 

To help expand her business, Rosemary has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more timber for sale, and will help Rosemary to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Rosemary hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her working capital. 

Rosemary is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rosemary who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more timber for sale

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is 39 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortpotal region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children with 3 of them currently in school. For the past 15 years, Ibrahim has been working hard to manage his retail shop where he sells essentials such as sugar and soap . 

To help expand his business, Ibrahim has requested a loan of 2,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. He will use the loan to buy more inventory to sell in his shop, items like sugar, soap, water, and bread. This will help Ibrahim to generate greater profits and, in turn, pay his children's school fees. Ibrahim hopes that, in the future, he will be able to buy another plot of land. 

Ibrahim is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). This program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Ibrahim, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, yet have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more inventory for his shop, such as sugar, soap, water, and bread.

loans.name: Carlos Roberto

texts.es: Carlos, tiene 39 años de edad, es soltero, vive junto a su hijo en una aldea de San Francisco de Yojoa. El inició con un negocio de vender jugos naturales de forma ambulante pero sus ingresos son muy pocos para sostener a su hijo. Hace 8 años decidió poner un negocio fijo como una pulpería donde vende productos alimenticios básicos como es arroz, frijoles, manteca, huevos, café, sal, azúcar, harina, refrescos, carnes, lácteos, churros etc. y también vende calzado y novedades. Con la inversión de prestamos a sostenido el negocio y lo ha hecho crecer. Actualmente solicita el tercer ciclo que es por 20,000 lempiras para seguir surtiendo el negocio con productos básicos como granos básicos, carnes, lácteos, golosinas, productos de aseo, novedades y calzado. Su plan es crecer mas para tener mas ganancias y mejorar su casa.
texts.en: Carlos is 39 years old. He is single and lives with his son in the town of San Francisco de Yojoa. He began with a business of selling natural juices as a street vendor, but his income was very little for supporting his son. Eight years ago he decided to set up a regular business such as a grocery store, where he sells basic food products such as rice, beans, lard, eggs, coffee, salt, sugar, flour, soft drinks, meats, dairy products, churros (a doughnut-like snack), etc., and he also sells footwear and novelties. With the investment from the loans, he has maintained his business and he has made it grow. Now he is applying for his third loan cycle, which is for 20,000 lempiras in order to continue stocking his business with basic products such as basic grains, meats, dairy products, candies, cleaning products, novelties, and footwear. His plan is to grow more in order to have more earnings and improve his house.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, meats, dairy products, candies, cleaning products, novelties, and footwear.

loans.name: Cornelius

texts.en: Hello! Cornelius is an ever-smiling, 30-year-old, hardworking, and honest man. He is happily married, and is blessed with one beautiful child, age 8 years. Still young and full of energy, he has been farming for the past ten years, and has been making profits. His farming involves feeding and tending to his animals. His primary source of income is selling eggs, maize, and vegetables, and some small business he does to make ends meet. When asked what’s the most enjoyable thing about farming, he answered, “I get food to eat and to sell”. Cornelius has expansive land, and has planted enough Napier grass. He has always wanted to buy a good breed of dairy cow, but has been challenged by a lack of finances. Through Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva, he will make his dream a reality. He underwent training with Juhudi Kilimo, and has learned that microfinances help the poor access financing, and help them in their projects. He says that with the loan he will increase his milk production, and therefore increase his income level. Profits from the loan will be used in repaying the loan and securing the future of his young family.

loans.use: To buy a good quality cow

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia is 46 years old and is married with 6 children. She runs a general store in the Philippines where she works hard to support her family.

Cynthia has been running her general store for 4 years now, but she also earns income from food vending. She has borrowed and successfully repaid 5 loans from Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation before her current loan request. 

Cynthia is now requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP through NWTF so she can purchase items to sell such as canned goods, beverages, groceries, etc.

Cynthia aspires to save enough money to be able to one day send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell like canned goods, beverages, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more of different kinds of fish to resell to his customers

loans.name: Jose Edwim

texts.es: Jose de 28 años de edad se dedica desde hace 10 años a la agricultura siembra maíz, comercializa sus productos en los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su casa, vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos en casa propia, Jose está solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, etc. y mejorar el terreno que muestra en la fotografía para poder continuar con su trabajo y tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en: José, who is 28 years old, has worked for 10 years in agriculture. He raises corn and sells his products in the various markets that are located near his house. He lives with his wife and their two children in their own house. José is applying for a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers, compost, pest controls, etc., and to improve the land that is shown in the photograph in order to be able to continue with his work and have better income.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, compost, pest controls, etc. and to improve his land

loans.name: Izabella

texts.en:
Izabella is a farmer living in Tolors village, Syuniq region. She lives with her husband and 21-year-old son.

Her husband is a migrant worker who works and lives abroad and supports his family financially. Izabella and her son are occupied in farming. They keep livestock of 20 sheep and 15 hens and also cultivate wheat, emmer wheat, and potatoes on their farm.

Izabella asks for this loan to be able to enlarge her farm. She plans to purchase 8 sheep, forage for the livestock, seeds (1 ton), and fuel for land cultivation. The loan will be a big assistance for this family, and Izabella hopes for lenders' support.

loans.use: to pay for sheep, forage for the livestock, seeds, and fuel for land cultivation

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
Florence is 57 years old, and has 8 children. She is a group leader, and is representing her group of 11 farmers in Teso District, Kenya. 

Florence has been farming with One Acre Fund since 2011. This decision was largely a result of her desire to have access to quality training, and to learn new farming methods. Although she described her last harvest as excellent, she believes she could have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. Florence also decided to purchase a solar light with part of her loan, which she is very excited about, as it will allow her to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel, and therefore save more money.

Obtaining this loan means that Florence's Group will be able to purchase a total of 8 solar lights, as well as seeds and fertilizer to plant a total of 5 acres.

loans.use: to purchase solar lights, and gain access to cost-effective hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: Con la ayuda económica que fue financiada por la cooperativa COMIXMUL en alianza con los diferentes inversionistas en la plataforma de KIVA Juana pudo comprar los diferentes insumos como: nutricafe, abono 18-46-0, abono foliar los cuales fueron aplicados a sus cultivos de café para obtener una excelente cosecha con la cual pudo cancelar su compromiso de manera satisfactoria. Gracias a dicho apoyo financiero fu posible obtener el rendimiento positivo de su plantación en la temporada para la cual resulto satisfactoria dicha inversión solicitando nuevamente un segundo financiamiento el cual invertirá en sus cultivos de café comprando fertilizantes y llevando a cabo el pago de mano de obra calificada la cual ayudara mucho más a que el tiempo invertido e insumos a aplicar sean muy bien aprovechados. Juana espera ser apoyada por los diferentes inversionistas en la plataforma de Kiva pues su deseo está enfocado en el crecimiento y mejoramiento continuo de propiedad y el apoyo en las vidas de cada uno de sus hijos.
texts.en:
With the economic aid financed by the COMIXMUL cooperative in alliance with different investors of the Kiva platform, Juana was able to buy different supplies, like: nutricafe, manure (18-46-0), and foliar fertilizer. These were applied to her coffee crops in order to obtain an excellent harvest with which she was able to pay her credit in a satisfactory way. 

Thanks to the financial aid it was possible for her to obtain a good output from her plantation during the season, and due to the optimal result of that investment she is now asking for a second loan which will be used to purchase fertilizers and to pay for specialized labor. This will help to make the most of the time and supplies invested in her coffee crops. 

Juana hopes to be supported by the different investors of the Kiva platform, since it is her wish to enhance her property and support each of her children.

loans.use: to buy supplies and pay for specialized labor to assist her coffee crops.

loans.name: Alex's Group

texts.en:
Alex is a 28-year-old proud father of 5 children. He is a group leader, often described as a very hardworking individual, and is representing his group of 8 farmers in Kakamega North District.

Alex described his harvest as good last year, but believes he can have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. He is very excited to also be purchasing a solar light, apart from fertilizer and maize, because he will now be able to have light during the dark hours for his children to be able to study. With the profits from this season’s harvest, he plans to buy a cow.

With this loan, Alex’s Group will be able to plant a total of 4.25 acres of land and purchase a total of 5 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Blanca De Jesus

texts.es: Blanca de 43 años de edad vive en casa propia con su compañero de vida y su hija, ella posee una pequeña tienda desde hace varios años ubicada en su lugar de residencia vende una variedad de productos como golosinas, refrescos, granos básicos, café, sopas, huevos, gelatinas, azúcar, etc. y tiene muchos clientes por los buenos precios, ella está solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas mercadería por mayor ya que esa es su única fuente de ingresos y así podrá tener mejores ganancias para una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Blanca, 43, lives in her own home with her life companion and their daughter.  

She has had a small store in her place of residence for several years, where she sells a variety of products such as snacks, soft drinks, basic grains, coffee, soup, eggs, jellies, sugar, and such; and she has a lot of customers because of her good prices.

She is requesting a loan for the purchase of more merchandise at wholesale, as that is her only source of income; and in this way, she will be able to have better earnings for a better quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase snacks, soft drinks, basic grains, coffee, soup, eggs, jelly, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Medren

texts.en: Medren is a twenty-eight-year-old married woman, with four children, living in Bundibugyo-Uganda. She has a retail shop in Bundibugyo where she sells general merchandise. She has managed it very well, and the proceeds from this business have helped her family with their basic needs. She wants to expand her business, although she is affected by seasonality and, like other retailers, price fluctuations. Medren has asked for a loan to buy general merchandise, such as curry powder, sugar, and wheat to sell.

loans.use: to buy general merchandise, such as curry powder, sugar, and wheat to sell.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is married, with seven children. She is 51 years old and has one child in school.

Editha is a very hardworking entrepreneur.  She has a bicycle-transport business in the Philippines.  She has requested a PHP 6,000 loan through NWTF to buy spare parts and other materials to use in her business.

Editha has been in this business for five years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and materials for her bicycle-transport business

loans.name: Keya's Group

texts.en:
Keya is a 59-year-old proud mother of 6 children. She is a group leader, often described as a very experienced farmer, and is representing her group of 16 farmers in Teso District. Since joining One Acre Fund in 2012, Keya has noticed that she has been able to consistently feed her family.

Keya described her harvest as good last year, but believes she can have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. She is very excited to also be purchasing a solar light, apart from fertilizer and maize, because she will now be able to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money. With the profits from this season’s harvest, she plans to send her children to school.

With this loan, Keya’s Group will be able to plant a total of 7.75 acres of land and purchase a total of 9 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Samir

texts.en:
Samir is a 28-year-old man who owns a small business. He is single and lives with his parents and sister in the Fuzuli region. His mother has been sick for long a time and his sister take care of their mother. Samir’s father is a teacher. Samir's family are IDPs (Internally Displaced Persons) from Füzuli City. 

He has a small store. In this store he sells various vegetables and fruits. He has been in this business for four years. Today he plans to buy new seasonal fruits and vegetables (carrots, beets, potatoes, onions, apples, and etc.). For this reason he needs 1,350 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat). Samir is thankful to Komak and Kiva for a loan. He is confident that this aid will help him increase his business and earn more money. In the future he wants to repair his store for his business. And in his personal life he wants to get married and to have three children.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to increase his business, and in future he wants to get married.

loans.name: Valientes Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “VALIENTES” iniciará el quinto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Santiago II, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Lidia es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de ropa, venta de comida, venta de papa y chuño, venta de refrescos, venta de cotillones, venta de polleras, venta de muebles, venta de mantas.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Lidia es integrante, ella indica que hace cuatro años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una amiga que es cliente de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio ropa; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió hace varios años al casarme emprendí un negocio independiente, ya que conocía la dinámica de comercio pues apoyaba desde niña a su madre. 

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de ropa por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo comercializará en su puesto de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la forma de trabajar que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The communal bank “Valientes” will start its fifth loan cycle in Pro Mujer, as part of the Centro Focal de Santiago II. It is formed by eight members and it is managed by a board of directors in which Lidia is the President. 

The businesses that the members of the communal bank have are diverse, and among them are the sale of clothes, food, potatoes and freeze-dried potatoes, beverages, party favors, traditional Andean skirts, furniture and blankets. 

The loan they are requesting will benefit the micro-entrepreneurs in which Lidia is a member. She says that she has been part of Pro Mujer for the last four years, and she entered by a friend’s request who is a client of the institution. 

Nowadays, she has a clothing business, and says that she started it several years ago when she got married. She wanted a business of her own and knew the dynamics of the trade since she supported her mother from an early age. 

The loan she is now requesting is to increase her capital (buy clothing in bulk) that will be acquired from the wholesalers of the city La Paz to then be sold at her stand. This type of work allows her to generate incomes to support her family financially, since she is married and has three children.  

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answers that she likes the way the institution works.

loans.use: to buy clothing in bulk.

loans.name: Pacajes Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “PACAJES” iniciará el décimo noveno ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Juan Pablo II, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Rita es la Secretaria. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de comida, venta de canastas, venta de queques, taller de chapería, venta de cobertores de autos, venta de mochilas, venta de muebles, venta de puertas.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Rita es integrante, ella indica que hace un año que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una amiga que es cliente de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio venta de cosméticos; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió hace varios años al observar el mercado y ver que este producto es ampliamente comercializado. 

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de cosméticos por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo comercializará a pedido de la clienta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es soltera.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Pacajes" will begin its nineteenth loan cycle with ProMujer as part of the Juan Pablo II regional center. It consists of eight members and is led by a board of directors where Señora Rita is the secretary. The businesses that the members of the bank run are varied. Among them are selling food, selling baskets, selling cakes, auto body shop, selling auto covers, selling backpacks, selling furniture, and selling doors.

The loan that they will take out will benefit these small business people, of whom Señora Rita is one. She indicates that she joined Pro Mujer a year ago, entering at the invitation of a friend who is a client of the institution. Now she has a business of selling cosmetics. She lets it be known that she undertook this business a number of years ago on observing the market and seeing that this product is widely marketed.

The loan that she will take out now is to increase her capital and buy cosmetics wholesale, which she will acquire from the wholesale vendors in the city of La Paz, and later she will sell them on order from the customer. This form of work allows her to earn resources to support her family economically, since she is single.

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responds that she likes the training that the institution offers.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics wholesale

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella is 44 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortpotal region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, 2 of them currently in school. For the past 5 years, Bella has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Bella has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more materials to make clothes for sale, and will help Bella to generate greater profits and buy some basic needs at home. Bella hopes that, in the future, she will be able to build some rental houses. 

Bella is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Bella who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more materials to make clothes for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sheets, beams, balconies, doors and windowpanes

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 28 years old, and married, with six children, living in Bundibugyo in Uganda. 

He buys and sells cocoa, and he has a cocoa garden that supplements his income.  He used the previous loan very well and realised profits out of it.  He still faces seasonality changes and competition, however.

Moses asks for a loan to buy cocoa to sell.

loans.use: to buy cocoa to sell

loans.name: Ermelinda

texts.en:
Ermelinda is 59 years old, and married with three children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Ermelinda runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a 6,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell, such as beverages, canned goods, shampoo, etc..

She has been in this business for 3 years and sells a variety of items such as biscuits, beverages, candies, vinegar, junk food, etc.. 

In the future, Ermelinda would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell, such as beverages, canned goods, shampoo, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay her next semester fees.

loans.name: Okemer's Group

texts.en:
Okemer is 55 years old and has 5 children. He is a group leader and is representing his group of 12 farmers in Teso District, Kenya. 

Okemer has been farming with One Acre Fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2011. This decision was largely a result of his desire to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods. Although Okemer described his last harvest as excellent, he believes he could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside One Acre Fund. Okemer also decided to purchase two solar lights as part of his loan, which he is very excited about, as it will allow him to reduce his consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money.

Obtaining this loan means that Okemer's Group will be able to receive a total of 10 solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 7 acres.

loans.use: to purchase two solar lights and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Juliendah's Group

texts.en:
Julienda is a 45-year-old proud mother of 6 children. She is a group leader, often described as a very experienced farmer, and is representing her group of 13 farmers in Kakamega North District. Since joining One Acre Fund in 2012, Julienda has noticed that she has had more profits from each harvest.

Julienda described her harvest as good last year, but believes she can have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. She is very excited to also be purchasing a solar light, apart from fertilizer and maize, because she will now be able to have light during dark hours for her children to be able to study. With the profits from this season’s harvest, she plans to send her children to school.

With this loan, Julienda’s Group will be able to plant a total of 7.75 acres of land and purchase a total of 10 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Silas's Group

texts.en:
Silas is a 60-year-old proud father of 5 children. He is a group leader, often described as a very hardworking individual, and is representing his group of 12 farmers in Kakamega South District. Since joining One Acre Fund in 2014, Silas has noticed that he has had a healthier life due to better nutrition.

Silas described his harvest as excellent last year, but he believes he can have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. He is very excited to also be purchasing a solar light, apart from fertilizer and maize. With the profits from this season’s harvest, he plans to repair his home.

With this loan, Silas’s Group will be able to plant a total of 6.75 acres of land and purchase a total of 8 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Alhaji Mohammed

texts.en: Alhaji Mohammed is a maize farmer from Tunkuna village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Alhaji Mohammed would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater to his immediate cash needs. With this loan, and Babban Gona’s support, Alhaji Mohammed can now store his maize at harvest time, and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Alhaji Mohammed, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Nyame Kyere Farm Group

texts.en:
Nana resides in Egyirkrom in the Abura Asebu Kwamankese District in the Central Region of Ghana. Nana is 55 years of age and married with 17 children, of whom 8 are currently in school. The ages of his 5 oldest children are as follows: 33, 30, 29, 27, and 26.

Nana is a farmer and has been in farming for the past 30 years. He has 20 acres of orange plantation. Nana does not want any of his children to go wayward, hence he works very hard to bring them up and give them a better education despite the large family size. He runs a commercial transport business as his other source of income.

Nana uses the income from his transport business to maintain his orange plantation, but this is not enough for Nana to meet expenditures he faces by expanding his orange plantation to generate more income to care for his family. He needs a microloan to undertake routine farm maintenance to increase crop yield and income. Nana is thankful to all his microlenders for their generous support.

loans.use: to weed the farm and to buy a fertilizer and food fly traps

loans.name: Atipiris Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ATIPIRI” iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Achacachi, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Rosa es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de queso, venta de papa, venta de semillas.
 
El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Rosa es integrante, ella indica que es la primera vez que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de un Asesor de la institución que fue a visitarle a su domicilio. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de producción y venta de queso; nos cuenta que este negocio lo aprendió de sus padres, pues desde niña apoyaba en el negocio familiar, ahora que tiene una familia independiente decide emprender su propio negocio.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de afrecho por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de la Ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente alimentará con ello a sus ganados. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, ya que ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones y la atención de la institución ofrece.
texts.en:
The communal bank “Atipiri” will start its first loan cycle in Pro Mujer, as part of the Regional Office of Achacachi. It is formed by eight members and it is managed by a board of directors in which Rosa is the President. The businesses that the members of the communal bank have are diverse, and among them are the sale of cheese, potatoes and seeds. 

The loan they are requesting will benefit the micro-entrepreneurs in which Rosa is a member. She says that it’s her first time at Pro Mujer, and she entered by the request of an advisor of the institution who visited her house.

Nowadays, she has a business making and selling cheese, and says that she learned this activity from her parents, since from a young age she had to help in the family business. Now that she has her own family she decided to start her own business. 

The loan she is now requesting is to increase her capital (buy bran) that will be acquired from the wholesalers of the city La Paz. Then she will use it to feed her cattle. This type of work allows her to generate incomes to support her family, since she is married and has two children.  

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answers that she likes the training and attention that the institution offers them.

loans.use: to buy bran in bulk.

loans.name: Joram

texts.en:
Joram is 42 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortpotal region of Uganda. He is married, and has 8 children, 6 of whom are currently in school. For the past 2 years, Joram has been working hard to manage his wholesale business, which sells sacks of dry food. 

To help expand his business, Joram has requested a loan of 2,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sacks of maize flour and beans to  sell, and will help Joram to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Joram hopes that in the future he will be able to own a very big supermarket. 

Joram is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joram who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of maize flour and beans to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more spare parts for the business

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is 31 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba in the Fortpotal region of Uganda. He is married and has two children. 

For the past eight years, William has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells fresh beef. 

To help expand his business, William has requested a loan of UGX 3,000,000 from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more fresh beef and goat meat for sale.  It will help William to generate greater profits and take good care of his family. 

William hopes that in the future he will be able to develop his business more. 

William is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like William who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more fresh beef and goat meat for sale

loans.name: Judith's Group

texts.en:
Judith, pictured above, has 5 children. She is always described as a very hardworking individual, which is why she was selected to become the leader of her group. Judith is representing her group of 14 farmers in Kakamega South District and is happy to be working with One Acre Fund for the first time this year.

Judith has been a farmer for more than 20 years and, in order to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods, she decided to join the One Acre Fund program this season. Her loan will include not only farming inputs but also a solar light. With the profits from this coming season, Judith is planning to send her children to school.

A total of 5.5 acres will be planted by Judith's Group, and between them they will receive a total of 7 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, as well as a solar light.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is 41 years old and married, with three children. With two children in school, Geraldine works very hard to provide for them.

Geraldine runs a general store in the Philippines.  She has requested a PHP 7,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell, like shampoo, cigarettes, canned goods, and beverages, etc.

Geraldine has been in this business for 12 years.  She sells a variety of items, such as snacks, soft drinks, canned goods, noodles, coffee, milk, etc. 

In the future, Geraldine would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell, like shampoo, cigarettes, canned goods, and beverages.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to help cover his next semester fees.

loans.name: Philimon's Group

texts.en:
Philimon is 37 years old and is often described as a very hardworking individual. He has one child and is married. As a group leader, Philimon is representing his group of 15 farmers in Kakamega South District in Kenya and is very excited to be working with One Acre Fund for the first time this year.

The decision to join One Acre Fund was largely a result of Philimon's desire to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods. Apart from receiving farming inputs, he is also purchasing a solar light as part of his loan. With the profits that he gains from this year’s harvest, he plans to send his children to school.

Philimon and his group will receive a total of 9 solar lights as well as input loans of maize and fertilizer to plant a total of 6 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Eliseus' Group

texts.en:
Eliseus is a 69-year-old proud father of 6 children. He is a group leader, often described as a very trustworthy person, and is representing his group of 14 farmers in the Teso District of Kenya. Since joining One Acre Fund in 2012, Eliseus has noticed that he has greater farm group support.

Eliseus describes his previous year's harvest as good, but he believes he can raise a better harvest this year by continuing his work with One Acre Fund. 

Eliseus is pleased to be purchasing fertilizer and maize seed with his portion of the loan. But, moreover, he is very excited to be purchasing a solar light, because he will now be able to reduce his consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money. 

With the profits from this season’s harvest, Eliseus plans to send his children to school.

WIth the other members' loan portions, Eliseus’s Group will be able to plant a total of 7.75 acres of land and purchase a total of 4 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Hellen's Group

texts.en:
Hellen is 31 years old and has 3 children. She is a group leader and is representing her group of 10 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya. 

Hellen has been farming with One Acre Fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2011. This decision was largely a result of her desire to get the best quality fertilizer and hybrid seeds. Although Hellen described her last harvest as excellent, she believes she could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside One Acre Fund. Hellen also decided to purchase a solar light as part of her loan, which she is very excited about, as it will allow her to have light during dark hours for her children to be able to study.

Obtaining this loan means that Hellen's Group will be able to receive a total of 3 solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 5.75 acres.

loans.use: to buy cost-efficient maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, as well as a solar light.

loans.name: Balastus' Group

texts.en:
Balastus is 71 years old and has 6 children. He is a group leader and is representing his group formed by 16 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya.

Balastus has been farming with One Acre Fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2011. This decision was largely a result of his desire to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods and, although he described his last harvest as very good, he believes he could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside One Acre Fund. Balastus also decided to purchase a solar light as part of his loan, which he is very excited about as it will allow him to have light during dark hours for his children to be able to study.

Obtaining this loan means that Balastus' Group will be able to receive a total of 6 solar lights as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 9.75 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Zaitun's Group

texts.en:
Zaitun, pictured above, has 9 children. She is representing her group, formed by 16 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya. Zaitun joined One Acre Fund for the first time in 2011, and decided to represent her group, because she wanted to be more active in her community.

With a portion of this loan, Zaitun will not only purchase maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, but also a solar light. Purchasing a solar light with part of her loan means that now she will be able to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel, and therefore save more money. Zaitun plans to use the profits she gains this year to send her children to school.

In total, Zaitun’s Group will use the money received from this loan to plant a total of 12 acres of land. They will also purchase a total of 2 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, as well as a solar light.

loans.name: Vicent

texts.en:
Vicent is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba in the Fortpotal region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children, 3 of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Vicent has been working hard to manage his charcoal business. 

To help expand his business, Vicent has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more sacks of charcoal, and will help Vicent to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Vicent hopes that, in the future, he will be able to see his business expand more. 

Vicent is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Vicent who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 27 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba in the Fort Potal region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the last three years, Agnes has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential items like sugar and soap.

To help expand her business, she has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential items like sugar, soap, water, and bread to sell, and will help Agnes to generate greater profits and take good care of her family. She hopes that in the future she will be able to expand into a wholesale business. 

Agnes is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP) which primarily serves small entrepreneurs who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell.

loans.name: Maria Arlett

texts.es:
María Arlett tiene 43 años de edad, es conviviente, tiene 2 hijos, vive en una zona rural del distrito de Oyotún, provincia de Chiclayo, región Lambayeque, costa norte de Perú. Su comunidad está dedicada básicamente a la agricultura, ganadería y al comercio.

María Arlett se dedica a la crianza y comercialización de animales, con más de 10 años de experiencia en el negocio, el mismo que está ubicado en su domicilio, ella solicita préstamo para mejoramiento de infraestructura de corrales, pues es en sus corrales donde ella cría a sus animales, dicha inversión le servirá para criar en mejores condiciones y mayor calidad a sus animales, con gran influencia en el negocio; María Arlett piensa mejorar productividad de los animales para poder atender las diversas necesidades y gustos de los clientes de la zona. Lo que le permitirá en un corto plazo mejorar sus ingresos, aumentar sus ganancias y por ende mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Maria Arlett is 43 years old, lives with her partner and has 2 children.  She lives in a rural zone of the Oyotun district, in the province of Chiclayo, Lambayeque region, in the north coast of Peru.  Her community is basically dedicated to agriculture, cattle farming and trade.

Maria Arlett makes a living raising and selling animals and has more than 10 years of experience in this business. The business is located in her home.  She is requesting this loan to improve the infrastructure of the pens, because it is in the pens where she raises her animals.  This investment will help her raise the animals in better conditions and get better quality animals, which will greatly effect her business.

Maria Arlett plans to increase the productivity of the animals in order to tend to the diverse needs and likes of her customers from the area. In the short run, this will allow her to improve her income, increase her profit and therefore improve the quality of life for her and her family.

loans.use: to improve the infrastructure of the animal pens.

loans.name: Glynish

texts.en: Glynish, 31 years old, is married and has two children in school. Glynish works very hard to provide for them. For the past 7 years, Glynish has run a general store in the Philippines, selling a variety of items such as biscuits, vinegar, junk foods, school supplies, etc. She has requested a PHP 9,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items such as beverages, eggs, canned goods, etc. to sell. In the future, Glynish would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional items such as beverages, eggs, canned goods, etc. to sell

loans.name: Christopher's Group

texts.en:
Pictured above is Christopher, often described as an extremely trustworthy person. He is 61 years old and, as a group leader, he is representing his group of 12 farmers in Teso District, Kenya.  He is married and has two children.

Christopher is returning this season to work with One Acre Fund again as this means that he is able to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods, which is why he decided to join in the first place. Christopher says that he is happy to have made that decision because, since he first joined in 2012, he has had a healthier life due to better nutrition, which has improved his day-to-day life significantly. Christopher will use the profits from this season to invest in a business.

The group will use this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer to plant a total of 6.5 acres. Given that some members of the group will also be purchasing a solar light, with this loan, the group will also receive a total of nine solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize.

loans.name: Hannah May

texts.en: As the married parent of two children, Hannah May works hard to support her family. She earns a living by buying and selling scrap in the Philippines, and also earns additional income by selling purified drinking water. Hannah May is requesting a loan for PHP 7,000 from NWTF to buy more scrap to sell. She has sustained her business with three prior loans from NWTF.
